D115BF880ACF4DCDB3F0842EE3EB0720.description:
Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of
each part as a unit fraction of the whole. For example, partition a shape
into 4 parts with equal area, and describe the area of each part as 1
4 of
the area of the shape.Â Â

79FE64643C1F43C9B14321C3C11D78B3.description:
Understand that shapes in different categories (for example,
rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (for example,
having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger
category (for example, quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses,
rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw
examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these
subcategories.Â

EFC96F2F61B54AA1A42743F58D18D4D0.description: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

B129499929F544AA96A7435078D5F8C2.description:
Solve real world and mathematical problems involving
perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side
lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with
the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and
different perimeters.

5D713A055D0D4C8AB1D868230FD4699A.description:
Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and
distinguish between linear and area measures.

6FE812774B7747668B45D211DA867730.description:
Recognize area as additive. Find areas of figures that can be
decomposed into non-overlapping rectangles and add the areas
of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve
real world problems.Â

57698DF23C094205ABCFD7D9142501B5.description:
Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle
with whole-number side lengths ð‘Žð‘Ž and ð‘ð‘ + ð‘ð‘ is the sum of ð‘Žð‘Ž Ã— ð‘ð‘
and ð‘Žð‘Ž Ã— ð‘ð‘ . Use area models to represent the distributive
property in mathematical reasoning.

4D32723303AF47A28FB8BF618AD09197.description:
Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and
mathematical problems.

B04552410D75486EB3FEFC9EED3A5D6B.description:
Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by
tiling it and show that the area is the same as would be found by
multiplying the side lengths.

45B3C07B86D04E969A62631D4FF3557C.description: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.

ECA8CE2A04194289B1E21B7BA4345F6B.description:
Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square
m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).Â

F289211E3FFD4E0499D84959DB29E0B5.description:
A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by
n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.Â

5879E54A70B842C8884D96648EE210B1.description:
A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to
have "one square unit" of area, and can be used to measure
area.

DFDF78858AC7455388CA16F8F1BC98BB.description:
Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and
understand concepts of area measurement.

90AC5CC3D0DE44C6BB9AE2AE927854F0.description:
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication
and to addition.Â

0FA135C663BD4C6D9EE7D96EF080DA5D.description:
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using
rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by
making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate
unitsâ€”whole numbers, halves, or quarters.Â

E5E23EE633094CF1BCC73C6796F1C467.description:
Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to
represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step
"how many more" and "how many less" problems using information
presented in scaled bar graphs.

C24BC9476A834507A75E4F5622E58D0B.description:
Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects
using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l) (Excludes
compound units such as cubic centimeters and finding the geometric
volume of a container.) Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve onestep word problems involving measured quantities (masses and liquid
volumes). Excludes multiplicative comparison problems involving notions
of "times as much"; problems do not require unit conversion.

12FB8C9746FA4403B80D267EF3FCED3A.description:
Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time
intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and
subtraction of time intervals in minutes. For example, by representing the
problem on a number line.

584DFEE0AF144EC59D973BD2B14261BE.description: Solve problems with time and measured quantities.Â

07D22747BEAD46A9BB4FF67E1083F584.description:
Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same
denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that
comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the
same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the
symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusion. For example, by
using a visual fraction model.

3FF613C3A1ED4FCFA8DE4E0CAD15FF85.description:
Express whole numbers as fractions and recognize fractions that
are equivalent to whole numbers. For example, express 3 in the
form 3 = 3
1
; recognize that 6
1 = 6; locate 4
4 and 1 at the same point
of a number line diagram.Â Â

CC8E19BA59334801A123D19677450ADD.description:
Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions. For
example, 1
2 = 2
4
,
4
6
= 2
3
. Explain why the fractions are equivalent.
For example, by using a visual fraction model.

DEEC63C816C643459BD013C9645ADDA2.description:
Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the
same size, or the same point on a number line.

54FF3C95C48045E5B160EF02C4E15A19.description:
Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases and compare
fractions by reasoning about their size.

A977B7EE48A049C5BFD457CAD5F862E3.description:
Represent a fraction ð‘Žð‘Ž
ð‘ð‘ on a number line diagram by marking off
ð‘Žð‘Ž lengths 1
ð‘ð‘ from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size
ð‘Žð‘Ž
ð‘ð‘ and that its endpoint locates the number ð‘Žð‘Ž
ð‘ð‘
on the number line.

F883A62685234DE7AF48FFA57FB06B20.description:
Represent a fraction 1
ð‘ð‘ on a number line diagram by defining the
interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into ð‘ð‘ equal
parts. Recognize that each part has size 1
ð‘ð‘ and that the endpoint
of the part based at 0 locates the number 1
ð‘ð‘
on the number line.

4E58123B06FB4F6A9F88C9B19861DFA3.description:
Understand a fraction as a number on the number line;
represent fractions on a number line diagram.Â

56D33083061A4BCE8A00E10141CB80AA.description:
Understand a fraction 1
ð‘ð‘ as the quantity formed by 1 part when
a whole is partitioned into ð‘ð‘ equal parts; understand a fraction ð‘Žð‘Ž
ð‘ð‘
as the
quantity formed by a part of size 1
ð‘ð‘
.Â

094AFA2F1A8246488E3802EF4998DD20.description:
Use place value and properties of operations to multiply onedigit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10â€“90. For example,
9 Ã— 80, 5 Ã— 60.Â

ACAAA5212B7F41EEA0DA987973B6A6AC.description:
Fluently add and subtract within 1,000 using strategies and
algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the
relationship between addition and subtraction. For example, 412 - 13
=412 -12 -1 = 400 -1 =399; 505+70 = 575.
Note: Fluency of this standard is critical by the end of grade level.

9F1F6D2AB80846E195C34CB03E16D9D3.description:
Round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100 within the
range of 0â€“1,000. For example, rounding 643 to the nearest 10 would be
640; to the nearest 100 would be 600.

165CCF96A67C4477940D976C7F7958AA.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multidigit arithmetic.

9AB6FF259B384CFDA56B6D37AA2A7783.description: Number and Operations in Base Ten

92CCA1111D3F4E1E8316FEC18A78A91E.description:
Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition
table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of
operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is always even,
and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal
addends.Â

8884BCCCA7B94B948B9C77B5D6538568.description:
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations.
Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the
unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental
computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Note: this standard is limited to problems posed with whole numbers and
have whole number answers; students should know how to perform
operations in conventional order when there are no parentheses to
specify a particular order (Order of Operations).

1E089B287E814BBBABEDB1DB405246E5.description:
Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in
arithmetic.

6C5E745DF80B44B981A0FDCA51C8DAE0.description:
Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such
as the relationship between multiplication and division or properties of
operations. For example, knowing that 8 Ã— 5 = 40, one knows 40 Ã· 5 =
8.
By the end of Grade 3, flexibly, efficiently, and accurately find all
products of two one-digit numbers.
Note: Fluency of this standard is critical by the end of grade level.Â

114E342625104B31BA29DCF435B7DFB1.description:
Understand division as an unknown-factor problem. For
example, find 32 Ã· 8 by finding (or remembering) the number that makes
32 when multiplied by 8 (â–¯ Ã— 8 = 32).

DAE14D12AB9F4855B157DCF6B9E759D1.description:
Use properties of operations as strategies to multiply and
divide. For example, if 6 Ã— 4 = 24 is known, then 4 Ã— 6 = 24 is also
known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 Ã— 5 Ã— 2 can be found
by 3 Ã— 5 = 15, then 15 Ã— 2 = 30, or by 5 Ã— 2 = 10, then 3 Ã— 10 = 30.
(Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8 Ã— 5 = 40 and
8 Ã— 2 = 16, one can find 8 Ã— 7 as 8 Ã— (5 + 2) = (8 Ã— 5) + (8 Ã— 2) = 40 +
16 = 56. (Distributive property.)

145EA7CCF735414D80F294F05FB90EAD.description: Use properties of operations and the relationship between multiplication and division.Â

FB8B0DF35A7D4CD195B9C50F990DA2F7.description:
Be able to represent a word problem by writing an equation
with a symbol for the unknown whole number and determine the
unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating to
three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that
makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 Ã— âŽ• = 48, 5 = âŽ• Ã·
3, 6 Ã— 6 = âŽ•.

920B211E9DD94EC7B9563C9B72232219.description:
Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word
problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement
quantities, with unknowns in all positions. For example, by using
drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to
represent the problem.

B82EDB12BCC8442284A5013CA02B8912.description:
Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers as the
number of groups or the number in each group in situations of equal
groups. For example, describe a context involving equal groups of
objects in which the number of groups or the number in each group can
be expressed as 56 Ã· 8.Â

7375811CB0E04CBEA6E890DDE564AA21.description:
Interpret products of whole numbers. For example, interpret
5 Ã— 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each;
describe a context in which a total number of objects can be expressed
as 5 Ã— 7.

A7A94E8C6D8441A29879EEDBC706331D.description: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.Â
